Non recommandé
11.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2015
This game isn't for everyone. It isn't even for the majority... It's for a small dedicated group of people.

I have a problem with procedurally generated. games. Occasionally the random variables all conspire to put a wall across the exit corridor, or make a 6-way symmetric equation solvable only by hours of trial and error... Sometimes you just don't know if you're being dense, or the game's given you an impossible level. When you play a human-crafted game, you know it's solvable. Not so with random games. Mirrormoon doesn't seem to have this problem because the 'randomness' is tightly controlled. It works like this: "If thing A is here, then puzzle B must need to be solved", and vice versa. Because every 'planet' is self-contained, the randomness is between planets...

So, it becomes clear that every sphere is basically a collection of the same puzzles, in slightly different configurations: You just randomly stumble about, trying to use the "mirror moon" as a map and do the exact same four or five 'puzzles', over and over again. Oh, the colours changed, and the placement of the puzzles changes.

So, why did I finish it? Because a) i'm a completist, b) I was playing a mature season, so winning was a lot easier, thanks to other players, and c) I figured out how to navigate about 1/10th of a second before uninstalling it.


You will enjoy this game if:
* You like games which tell you literally NOTHING, and let you figure it out for yourself.
* You like games which don't have an actual purpose, i.e. goal / FMV cutscenes etc...
* You like games which don't reward you with an attaboy, your reward is wholly inside yourself: That feeling of satisfaction you get when you see something new and think "Hey, I found that!".
* You like games which frustrate the absolute bejesus out of you for hours or days on end, and then *click* You get that five seconds of clarity, which wipes away those five days where you've been quiet, pensive, irritated at the world, and gone and written a sharply negative review on Steam: You go back to steam, change your review, and dive back into the 'game', and find that your clarity has paid off.
* You like games which give you clues which may (or may not) actually lead anywhere.
* You like games which just shows you stuff, and it's up to you to decide if it's a clue, or just procedurally generated fluff.


So, this is still a negative review, so what follows are SPOILERS.. Only read below if you are stuck and just want to know some clues:

The cockpit is laid out pretty logically. Power and fuel on the left, lights at the bottom right, rotation and translation at the right.
That casette tape at the bottom.. is just a selection between the tutorial and the main game. Once you've done Side A, flip it to Side B and leave it
What you're trying to do is.. get to a particular 'star' in the galaxy. You are in a so-called space ship, you use the button by the casette tape to 'beam up and down' to a planet's surface
You use the map to... wander around the galaxy trying to find your way to that star
The 8-track cassette thing is some kind of 'power diverter'. Put it into the right-hand slot, and pull the breaker to its right to warp to the currently highlighted star. In the left-hand-slot, you use it to beam down
The map is.... Bloody hard to use, it's so zoomed in, it's practically a hindrance. You can 'free-look' around the cockpit with RMB, but that's just disorienting too.
The general flow of the game is... Wander around totally randomly, doing each 'planet'.. You can spend hours and hours doing this for NO purpose. Eventually you will find an 'observatory' (where eventually can be up to several days of continuous play if you're unlucky! (this is what I hate most).
So after wandering around aimlessly... when you find the observatory planet (one which has the usual puzzles plus one more building), you get some nonsense about constellations. Ignore them, pointless. Just look for the 'ringed' star. That's where you're going. Around it there'll be a named star. Find the closest, and then beam up to search for it in your map. It may take hours and hours of painful searching to find it. Warp to that star, and then go back to the 'aimless wandering' step..
And then?.. just keep doing that.. eventually you should be, by random chance, in the vicinity of the goal star/planet. Make sure you spend many many hours of the aimless wandering.. This game is predicated on you wasting absolutely sh1tloads of time.
There's no way of going faster? In theory, you could use triangulation. pick three named stars which form a triangle around the destination star on an observatory planet, print the screen and get a ruler to calculate the distance of the circled star from them. get their coordinates in the cockpit, then use Scilab to calculate the vector composition of the three position deltas, weighted for distance . You should end up with a vector Next, use Excel to make a calculation, and then plug in star values. B4ll4che. Pointless, and ultimately unrewarding, so don't bother..
Should I play this game? Only if you've got nothing better to do!

On the surface of planets
*I find my way around by... By and large, just walking until you find something.. Get into the habit of walking forwards, and tapping left every few seconds.. That'll make a spherical spiral search pattern. Tedium++
*What's the moon for? ... You can use it as a map. You show up on it too as an arrow when it's in front of the sun, or you can use it as a gravitational 'magnet' to suck buildings out of the ground
*What's the buildings for?.. Some contain bits for your gun which let you manipulate the moon, or shoot markers. Some act as switches for other buildings when you walk through them. Some are just tourist attractions, or in-jokes to other Steam games
*What's the triangle marker things whizzing by? They help you find your way between buildings. *Follow them forwards, or backwards. When they reach where they're going they often make a building appear.
* There's nothing on this planet! There probably is, it's just that its one of those awful procedurally generated ones where the map is pointless, and the exit is somewhere on the far side from the moon, and it's not in occlusion, so the moon's not acting as a map. They bug me to hell. Spiral search your way out
* All I found was an exit, but there's 'atmospheric stuff'.. It's possible that you missed the 'moon mover' bit for your gun. Move the moon, and some buildings might appear when the sun goes away or comes back.
* What's the marker attachment for the gun for? It lets you 'press a button' for one of the puzzles. Also can potentially help with the map when there's no eclipse.
* I can not find my way off this planet at all press Escape.. Move on. It's not worth it.
* How do I know it's an observatory? I've found that mostly the stars are blue, rather than white. Also, you'll see random lines connecting some of the stars. These are constellations (in the game). The star you're looking for is ringed
* and then...? Well, this is where it gets annoying. The constellations are /sort of/ picked out if you press the slidey latch button at the bottom right of the screen. If you take some notes on the surface of the planet, you can /sort of/ find them again and then use the consellation stars to find yours. [/spolier]
* All the stars are XXX/## You're S.O.L It's a new season, so no help from other players. Good luck
 
Dark Blue Monkey

Produit reçu gratuitement

It's one of those puzzle games where to goal is not to solve a puzzle but to figure out what the puzzle is by solving it on accident through trial and error. I completed the first puzzle (A side) but the B-side didn't seem to make any more sense so I just quit. There is intrique to get you hooked, and there is obfuscation for the sake of it that just leaves you lost and confused, this game is the latter.

Blünderboy

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 février 2014
When I first learned of this game I was very intrigued and looked forward to it. Mirror Moon is an abstract game with all the implictations of that abstraction. There are no instructions and results of randomly clicking around the interface do very little to help you understand how the game is actually experienced. Tie that to a control scheme that is unfriendly to mouse users and this game is difficult to recommend. There is no means of looking up or down; this is extremely frustrating when trying to determine your location.

The game indicates that other planets are named by other players which makes this by definition an MMO game. No game that calls itself "single-player" should require a new player to seek out videos, forums, or other player assistance just to learn how to play it.

After more than two hours of play and the game is still obtuse and inscrutable, it becomes nothing more than an exercise in frustration. Cannot recommend until the game designers make it more friendly to new players.
 
Chucklebags

97 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2018
This showed up as a game that is similar to first person puzzle games (Portal 2, Quantum Conundrum, etc.). Seemed like an interesting game. Turns out it is more style than substance. I genuinely have no clue what I am doing. I tried to give it a good two hours to see if I could figure it out. I am just as lost 10 minutes in as 110 minutes in.

You know how traditonal first person games control with WASD (left stick on controller) to move your body around and the mouse (right stick on controller) to move your head around? This game combines the two controls, forcing you to always look towards the horizon. Can't look up or down. This becomes a problem once you figure out the planet in the sky is a map of the planet you are on.

You can interact with this planet and this is the only cool thing about this game. If you shoot a beam to the planet in the sky, it affects the planet you are on. If you move the planet away from the light, it can change what the planet is experiencing by gravity and lighting conditions. Darkness is your friend because the map will only show your position when this lighting condition is active. In the light, it disappears! I feel extremely dependent on the planet in the sky so that way I know where I am going, but with the limited FP controls and hiding my position on it with daylight, it makes you feel pretty helpless and you can easily get lost.

For a Unity game, very well optimized. No lag, probably on the lowest end of machines. I had like 400FPS, but I turned on vsync so that way it's less intense on my hardware, even though it is to reduce screen tearing. That's a preference that I like a lot.

Pass on this game.
 
wildgoosespeeder
489 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Non recommandé
2.1 h en tout

0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2015
Mirromoon EP recreates the experience of playing video games WAY back in the day.

In the 80s and early 90s, video games were much more mysterious than they are now. Games were made on MUCH smaller budgets by companies who were generally far less "professional" than modern studios. There was never a "tutorial level" in the game itself. The basic controls were (hopefully) described in the manual that came packaged with the game, and beyond that, you were usually on your own. There was no internet.

Under these circumstances, just figuring out how a game worked, could actually be part of the challenge of the game. That is the experience that Mirrormoon EP tries to create for the player, and I think it absolutely succeeds. Whether or not you enjoy it, depends on whether or not you enjoy that particular experience.
 
Sentient Goo
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mai 2015
I really wanted to like this game. I love the environment, the ambient music is cool and the stylistic choice of having the player rely on experimentation instead of giving you lots of direction reminds me of other games I really enjoyed like FarSky and Sword & Sworcery.

However, the controls are atrocious. WASD moves your character, but the big issue is you can't look around with your mouse. Instead, your mouse controls a giant moon in the sky that functions like a map to find things. You can only see this moon from certain points on the planet you are on and only facing in certain directions, so you basically have to give it a shot in the dark to find anything.

There is nothing more frustrating in a game than knowing what you are supposed to do, but not being able to do it because the design of the game sucks.

This method of exploration ruins what is probably an otherwise really cool experience.

I once went back and played Turok on the N64, only to find the controls feel really, really dated by now. This game isn't very old, but the controls feel worse than that.

Shame. That cockpit had me all excited. I was really hoping for more.
 
cowbells
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Game seems interesting, but theres no tutorial or decent guide so far that explains what I have to do. So I gotta give this a thumbs down. A good game doesn't have you doing random things like pushing buttons on a cockpit.

DragonFax
1,991 produits enregistrés
0
11 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2013
To all the people who think, they buy an actual Co-Op game with this, don't get fooled, this can't really be played together.
All, that can be done, is name planets and have other users explore these. (I got this from an external source. I have not used the feature myself, since the game on its own is difficult to figure out.)

The graphics are nice and simple, though really, they don't do much for the quality of the game.

The soundwork is futuristic and pleasant to the ears.

The controls are absolutely atrocious. The pointing thing moves extremely slow, and in most of the cases, the game gets minimized when i move the mouse too far and click (I have 2 screens, which might be the problem)

The fact, that you can't really look down is confusing and annoying because you have to constantly look down, which goes really heavy on the eyes.

All in all: I'm sure, this game is good for people who got a lot of time on their hands / People who really like exploring simple landscapes, but not for people who are big fans of games with actual player interaction
 
subscrine for more
363 produits enregistrés
3
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juillet 2015
What a boring game.

The graphics make Cybercon 3 look sophisticated. The sound is....non existent. The gameplay is dull as ditchwater. You're given no clue what to do, and you just spend hours and hours wandering round barren, empty, crudely drawn polygon worlds. You can't even look around freely.

It's not intuitive, it's not friendly, and it's not fun. Some of the other reviews say how frustrating the game is, then give it a recommendation anyway. Why? It's clearly not finished. This is a tech demo of some sort. It's missing a tutorial, a user guide, a plot and a purpose. Oh, and if someone could finish the graphics that'd be great, thanks.

Évaluation publiée le 4 octobre 2017
Mirrormoon's weird, minimalist art style is kind of interesting for a while- the spaceship controls in particular are actually really neat and imaginative- but it's ultimately more confusing than fun. When you solve a puzzle, it's vaguely satisfying, but there's a whole galaxy of... same-y looking planets, and zero guidance as to why or what to do.

Évaluation publiée le 13 juin 2015
Did you like Proteus? If the answer is no, you have a good taste, hence you won't like this neither. Another IGF seal of crap; if you see that symbol on a game front page, beware!

A barren planet where you can't even look around, and expend your time wondering what's going on. This is the equivalent of today's modern piece of art, where an apple with a turd on top is display on a crystal box. If you think that can't be made into a game is because you haven't try this software preparation yet. This is not even a game. Don't insult hard working developers calling this a game. This is the homeotherapy of games.

Another victim of the Steam Return policies. Finally, you stupid scamers are getting what was coming for you long time ago.

EDIT: Just forgot this. They even had the indecency of referencing the Atlas of No Man Sky in the space ship. As if any approach of the procedural work done in NMS is to be seen in here. So in case that there is any doubt, this is nothing like NMS. Avoid like the plague.

Non recommandé
0.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2016
Produit remboursé

The controls really suck, WASD to move is the ONLY way to move around a spherical planet. W/S move forward and backward, A and D rotate. So you can't pan to either side, and you can't look or point your gun thing anywhere except where you are currently facing. It was super frustrating to try to navigate around in 3D, especially since you're on the surface of a ball, with such bad controls.

I guess I didn't give this much of a chance, but I couldn't really see what I was supposed to be doing next, there was no option to get help in-game, and the controls were driving me mad.

Will be getting a refund.

Caveat Emptor (Buyer Beware) this game a poorly executed concept, once you beat the first moon there is nothing else to do, the game has a poor replay value because of the inability to progress, there is supposed to be a second moon but the developers should have instantly taken you there instead of making you find it, which not only is boring but puts a heck of a strain on your fingers, and I played with all possible means of controlling it.

Concept 10/10 Execution 1/10 Sound 7/10 Gameplay 1/10 Graphics 5/10 Overall 24/50

amd133mhz
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 novembre 2016
Produit remboursé

I don't know what this game tried to accomplish but it failed at it.
Firstly it looks like a sci-fi setting which made me assume it had some kind of story but it didn't have any. It neither had any charming atmosphere whatsoever.

There is no tutorial and game doesn't tell you what to do or give any objective. You need to find what works and that's frustrating because you don't need to think about it, you just try everything and get lucky in the process. Therefore there is no sense of accomplishment in finding what works.

I admit I didn't play it long enough to see if it had some redeeming qualities in it but Unfortunately I got bored of this game very quickly and I asked for a refund because it has some fundamental problems especially with it's controls.

You play the game from first person perspective but your head movement is nonexistent which gives the feeling that you're controlling a disabled astronaut.

Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2014
There is a difference between a challenging puzzle and something that's overly cryptic, and forces you to guess blindly.

This game is challenging, but most importantly NOT FUN! The camera and controls really piss me off. This is an "exploration" game where you can't even look up! I mean really how are you suposed to explore when you can't even move your head in more than 2 deminsions? It's like playing wolfenstien or doom back in the old days, and I don't mean that in a good way.

And worst of all these backwards ass mechanics are intergral to solving the puzzles and finding your way around (facepalm).

Skip this game, and if you want something similar (but not sucky) try Anti-Chamber, which was truly an awsome game.

4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2016
MirrorMoon EP... goodness... where do I begin? It is literally the most bewildering game I've ever laid my eyes upon, even more disorienting than Antichamber, which was designed to be disorienting. The game is divided into a vast array of planets with unique names, and they all play out the exact same way: walk, collect some artefacts, rotate the moon, collect more artefacts, rotate the moon again, win... boring. I bought the game thinking it would be an entertaining, music-based platformer, but there's no platforms! The only visible structures have absolutely no collision detection, and the music can barely be passed off as music! The one credit I can give this game is that it was a stepping stone for the developer, who went on to release Fotonica for Steam and iOS.
 
Jack5
257 produits enregistrés
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mars 2023
MirrorMoon EP is an ancient game from 2013. It's a whopping 10 years old at the time of this review. The game, at least, is an almost unique premise, with gameplay very much like an incredibly shallow No Man's Sky, but without graphics, crafting, advanced procedural generation, or any of the rest of that compelling stuff that made NMS successful. Or maybe this is a bit more like Elite, but without trading, with a walking sim slapped on top. The controls and gameplay are deliberately obtuse as you're intended to "work it out", this isn't actually "fun", but then if the devs had a clear idea what consists of "fun", we wouldn't be here in the shovelware section of Steam, would we.

There's a "multiplayer" aspect in that, much like NMS and Elite Dangerous, you get to name the planets you land on if nobody else did. That's multiplayer, right? I guess? Ok, maybe not.

Somewhat original premises aside, games are usually only successful when they're fun, coupled with great visuals and polished to the end of the earth and back. Unlike MirrorMoon EP, which is none of those things.

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The game features lazy minimalist/untextured low-polygon "retro" assets and visuals, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the early 1990s. The lack of textures is a method that lazy devs often use to disguise their lack of talent/interest in doing the graphics properly and trying to disguise it under the name of "art", or "We made it look bad on purpose", which really isn't something gamers should have to put up with. It's unclear why the developers weren't willing to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets and high resolution textures for the game. It looks bad as a result of their decisions, and that's just another reason to avoid it.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

MirrorMoon EP didn't appeal much to the people who own a copy of the game, either. It has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game didn't really capture any interest from gamers. The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for landing on a planet someone else already landed on (pretty much one of the first things you do if you actually play the game), but only around 32 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game. Hardly a success story, gamers just weren't all that interested in the game.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game. But this only appears around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on. A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it. We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

MirrorMoon EP is has the eye watering price of $15 USD, and it's not worth it. The developer seriously thinks this game is the same value as similarly priced games like Ark: Survival Evolved, Middle Earth: Shadow of War, The Mass Effect Trilogy, and The Witcher III: Wild Hunt. What a joke. $15 USD price tag, we should at least get textures on our polygons.
 
Obey the Fist!
8,761 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0

Évaluation publiée le 23 décembre 2022
Mirrormoon EP is a very original concept. As the name implies, each planet has a moon which acts a mirror that shows you everything on the planet, including your own location. I enjoy it because of the unique atmosphere, virtually endless planets to explore, and the challenge of solving the overarching mystery of the main game.

12.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 aout 2022
Exploring the rules and understanding them is a a fundamental part of the experience. The sense of mystery and wonder is spot on. The sensory feedback is pleasant, atmospheric, and builds up on the whole vibe. It also becomes a nice collaborative experience to find the ending - you can do this on your own way too though, if you want to solve the puzzle of the galaxy solo.

Definitely late to the party, but this is a game I really like.
 
Bloodybdgr
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2022
MirrorMoon EP wants to be a game packed full of intrigue, but only manages obscurity.

The opening thirty seconds or so of the game is a sequence of buttons you must push, in order; there is only one button active at a time, and that is the the button you must push. The entirety of "Side A", the first half hour or so of the game, was the same. There is one and only one thing to do. Find it, do it, move on.

The obscurity leaks into parts of the game design where it absolutely does not belong. The controls, for example, are deliberately extremely limited and painful. You are travelling across the surface of a small sphere (presumably the moon of the title), and can only move forward or backward, rotate left or right. DOOM 1993 controls, but very, very slow. It's an artificial barrier that I think is meant to enhance the sense of mystery the devs were clearly after, but all it manages to be is irritating, which is, I think, an apt description of the whole game.

I won't be giving MirrorMoon EP any more of my time.
 
CheerfulSpider
0

Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 mars 2022
"Recommend" isn't really the right word. This game definitely won't appeal to most people.
The design is pretty much the opposite of how most games are set up: it doesn't tell you anything about how anything works you just figure it out through trial and error. There's also no real goal (other than completing the designed level by getting the B-side of the cassette in your ship).
But overall that's what makes the game appealing - the whole thing feels all the more like an adventure in outer space because of the lack of hand-holding and the sense of mystery.

Dedi Chan

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Non recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 avril 2021
Le jeu est vide, pas d'histoire, pas d'explication, ambiance très pauvre, que ce soit visuellement ou musicalement. On peut explorer une quantité assez énorme de planètes qui se ressemblent toutes, avec des "énigmes" toujours similaires (en gros marcher et trouver les quelques structures présentes, puis retourner au vaisseau). Les voyages entre chaque planète sont en temps réels, ce qui ici veut dire entre quelques secondes et quelques dizaines de minutes à attendre dans un "vaisseau" (plutôt une interface avec différents tableaux sur sa position).
Je l'ai eu pour 1€50 et je regrette malgré tout mon argent; si vous achetez le jeu, ne le prenez surtout pas à son plein prix, c'est du vol.
Il n'y a rien à voir et rien à y faire, une réelle perte de temps.
 
tanghus1er

DwaCztery | Anon

Évaluation publiée le 5 juillet 2019
I think I've had MirrorMoon EP for years and thought the concept was beyond my comprehension. Perhaps I was mistaken. I think I am getting it. What seemed like a complex control panel that rivaled the puzzles of "Myst" are actually quite intuitive and I am able to pretty much go where I want in space. I've played about two hours and, through minimal trial and error, things are making logical sense to me. There seems to be thousands of places to explore and some seem malevolent just through a drastic change of atmosphere (both visual and aural). I recommend it. If I can figure it out, then I assume most people can.

82 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2018
Tags: 1PSCIWS - First P. Scifi Walksim
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content&Remove from Library

TLDR: No Man's Sky, Walking Simulator version. Solo play about 1 hour past the cryptic, unclear progression. Rest of game is recycling.

This is a game in which you are presented with a galaxy map and planet exploration. Unfortunately all of it is smokes and mirrors. The solo has a series of puzzles mostly involving assembling and disassembling a light gun, chasing tracers of landmarks around tiny barren planets and rotating the moon around.

The controls are very unwieldy, with the mouse/keyboard integration really clashing with each other. The idea to use the moon as a map was quaint and the illusion of free roam was actually convincing.

The multi is basically just a race against the clock to name everything. Each planet takes a small sampling of the puzzle chain from the intro/single playe rand throws it in there randomly generated. Which means planets can have nothing to do, a single trigger, or a chain of small events that more or less reflect a portion of solo.

Altogether the game gets old very quick. there is no real progression to be had outside of bragging rights and claiming planets for a group if you are into that sort of thing. Then again it is also not clear how many of those are from actual players or if there is a portion of it that is game generated so things never are completely stale.

Conclusion: I would seriously play No Man's Sky instead of this, at least it has some semblance of pretense at minecraft-like mechanics and wildlife. This is very barebones in comparison. Do not waste your time.
 
2nd Class Janitor - Wilco

The idea of exploring planets and naming them beside other players was interesting, but ultimately MirrorMoon EP is just a lonely experience with boring gameplay. Artifacts are sometimes dropped as easter eggs alluding to other games, but I couldn't possibly justify playing long enough to find and appreciate them.

This got stale far too quickly.

Évaluation publiée le 3 septembre 2017
A very intriguing and visually beautiful game. It takes a while to get the hang of it. The controls are not explained, at all. To understand the gist of the game, you either need to spend an extended amount of time attempting to learn, or read up on it. Once you do get the hang of it, it's a very interesting puzzle game. I was able to acquire all achievements. I absolutely love the visuals. I really do recommend this game, although I would understand your initial frustration.

1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 avril 2016
You're in a spaceship. There's nothing but a few dials and nodes. There's a map of the stars on one LCD screen. You mess around, press a few buttons, there's clicking and whirring and a few lights come on, illuminating your controls.

You eventually press down a lever and suddenly, you're on a strange, red planet. The surface is round, and it appears that this particular planet is rather small. You begin to walk. Ages pass, you do not notice. Eventually, you reach a palace made of light. On a pedestal sits a device.

You pick up the device, and it hums with a strange light. You can feel the universe bend.

You move on.

Évaluation publiée le 12 mars 2016
I can understand the mixed reviews. This game is not for everyone.
Too bad that the big red sign will keep most people out of this cool experimental game.


Most reviews already state enough about the gameplay.
I just want to say that anyone that played games like Proteus and liked it will probably enjoy this.
One long very cool puzzle (more of this please game devs), a complicated spaceship panel, strange multiplayer ideas, cool music and that one strange planet everyone is searching for. I play it from time to time again just to chill a bit.

Thats it. Sorry if my english has problems, I'm german.

Évaluation publiée le 25 février 2016
February 25th, 2016

I will play this again, but my first reaction is one of frustration. Even though I wanted to play a game like MirrorMoon, the controls and tutorial are frustrating. What's it like? It's like being tied to a motorized wheel chair, with your head locked so that you can only look straight ahead.

I will give this another try because there are some glowing reviews about MirrorMoon, but I have a feeling that like a lot of "great art," some people love to see genius in trash because it makes them seem special. We'll see. I'll change the review if my next try is more rewarding.

February 27th

Okay, I gave this another try, and I managed to make some progress. There is a good deal of satisfaction when you fumble along and figure things out, but I still don't understand the restrictive point of view. The game has earned one more try, but the rating stands. I think Mirrormoon's biggest flaws are interface and advertising; they aren't getting their point across to their audience.

Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2016
This is not your everyday game. I'm not quite sure it is a game per say. Maybe it's therapy.
The mechanics are minimalistic but, like the graphics, they create a universe where you love to get lost.
My only problem with this game is that the learning curve is very steep and it can be frustrating at the begining, thankfully there a great guides out there but they do spoil the discovering part.

I love the lonely lost-in-the-desert-mood, the beautifull graphics, and i would recommend it to people who want to experience something else than a space shooter.

Recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2016
Update October 2016:
While there are alot of newcomer people who just played this games recently doesnt have any clue about what this game is about. Me as the old player , the one that played it after the mid early stage of the release still have a lot of love and fun with it.

ABOUT MIRRORMOON EP
This game is sure about all exploration, without clue and you have to figure out what this is about. Luckily i found lots of information at the community hub at that time where lots of people still playing. Still playing to solve the puzzle together.

To tell you straight , Mirrormon EP is a puzzle game where everything is a puzzle . figuring out what to do and what is the next thing to do is a puzzle and mystery on its own.
Back then it was fine when the community is till alive and help each other alike. I think the new player that are playing recently are just lazy to go to the community hub or either the community is not there anymore to help with information.

This game come in SEASONS, where everyone is connected to the season server. In naming and exploring every planet you found in the system.
Its so fascinating that the space exploration in such grand scale can be done in this game. What i mean grand is the number of planets that you can visit. Although every planet does have similar kind of puzzle that you have to finish, you can also find a lot of different artifacts and things on some of them. The best thing of this all is you can name the planet as you want. As long as the planet hasnt been visited by other player and named by them. And yes this game is connected to the whole server with other player , although you can physically connects to them. (find it simmilar to NMS, where ther probably follows the same idea)


The end puzzle (or the main goal if how i should address it) is by finding the key planet of the system in that SEASON , by unlocking clues and information that are gathered from the community that played it together in that SEASON. (You can find all the guides and information in the comm hub) Once you found the key planet and solve the puzzle you basicaly finishes that season . And the entire community can transcend (continue) to the next season with and starting from zero.

TL:DR
This game is about pure exploration and pure puzzle. It is really recommended for hardcore puzzle player and gamer with determination. This game is connected for all player in SEASON. The Task of the game is to find the "KEY" Planet and solve its puzzle in order to complete the SEASON. That can be achieve through several steps and if better from the community joining together . Sadly the community is not alive anymore hence there are a lot of confusion to newcomer trying to figure out what this game is all about.

I know its kinda frustatring that you dont know what to do with the game, but if you are willing, with patience anc curiosity this game will be immense you with its delicacy. Just take your time to find the proper information from the ancient people (the old community) and you will understand what this is all about.


My Old Review:

Eventhough i have few hours of gameplay this game still gives me the lasting impression . Its amazing on how simple the game is but complex and mindblowing at the same time.

This game is a wonder , abstract work of art. Where you figure out everything by yourself. How the game works, how to progress, or to complete the game.
Immerse yourself into the atmosphere of space and nothingness. Best one i have experience.

One of the best atmospheric ,puzzle and exploration game !

1,624 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 janvier 2016
The game starts off great with what looks like a hint of a story, a visually striking setting then, after you figure out the needlessly limiting controls (you can't move or look around freely), a fantastic puzzle. After that it enters into a randomly generated boring star cluster with its own extremely obtuse puzzles, no explanations or basic context, an insanely complex non intuitive spaceship exploration system and just plain bad game design. There is no sense of progress, no drive to accomplish anything, it is plain and boring and intentionally obtuse rather than intelligently difficult to understand. I spent a long time trying to figure out a puzzle only to find that there is no progress indicator, no way of knowing what you're doing, how well or even why. Figuring out how to actually make the environment react at all is also a challenge that isn't always pleasing either. No hint system and no proper walkthrough since there are random puzzles don't help take the edge off in case figuring out useless stuff is not your thing. The game looked great in the trailer but sadly I cannot recommend it, there's just too much bad game design here despite a relatively strong start.
 
gordonfreeman01
3,215 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 janvier 2016
A game about exploration and discovery, with some clever puzzles along the way. Best played with a friend over Skype, so you can discover the wonders of MirrorMoon EP together. (Each "season" is its own persistent universe, so make sure you join the same one as anyone you want to play with.)

Side A gave me a sense of discovery and "Oh...Oh!....OHHHH!", as clanmurph put it, that I haven't had since I played the original Portal. Side B, similarly, is all about organically discovering the rules, mechanics, and objectives of the game, but at a much slower pace, and with a much greater emphasis on exploration.

The game took me 10 hours to beat, although YMMV, as it largely depends on what you randomly find as you explore. This was also the first game in a long time that forced me to take down notes with a pen and paper, as well as compulsively screenshot everything.

This game gave me the break I needed from overdosing on Fallout 4, and I can highly recommend it to anyone who wants to be set loose in a world where they have to figure everything out for themselves from the ground up.
 
Allus

It's not for everyone, and thats ok, because the people it's for will love it.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
22.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 décembre 2015
This game is unique.

It's a mixture between art and puzzle.
Very atmospheric and relaxing - no action, no stress. Good soundtrack.

I think the reason why many people dislike this game is because they don't know how to "play" it and correspondingly have no aim (and it's part of the game to find that out respectively "create" one) - or were expecting something else.

It has a notably unique feature i appreciate indeed: the strange mixture of a single player game in some kind of mmo - hive.



STRONG SPOILER AHEAD!


The game setting:

You're out in a universe, controlling a spaceship. The universe is generated randomly every season. Your aim, if you want, is to find the planet, on which the anomaly is located. This planet puzzle acts similar to the planet you played in the tutorial (before you get in your spaceship for the first time).

You get clues where this planet is located via other planets that show starconstellations when you visit them, mostly called (by the community) observatories or map planets. You've got to wirte down the planet coordinates. The more observatories you find, the easer you may locate the anomalie. Often people write those coords in the forum to help each other.

Those coordinates are a kind of border, if you connect them you narrow down the place where the anomaly can be. (See older Forum posts how to do that exactly - but better find it out yourself cause thats the game!)

My personal experience:

The single player part:
You're alone, never meet some one or directly play together or against .

The mmo - hive kind of thing part:
The planets will be named by the first person who solves the puzzle.

The mixture:
So you will see - as time passes by - that former unnamed planets will now have names, given by other players (or by you).

That gives me a kind of feeling "hey, you're not alone out there!" And i start thinking: "Maybe we should work together" But how to communicate? Well, via Steam - Forum. So, if you find actually people playing it at the same time and know how to communicate - this game is unbeatable in atmosphere, fun, chill-factor and brain-usage. You start to feel being part of a goal that only can be reached together.
 
Zuul
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 octobre 2015
Oh for a neutral button for these reviews.......

This game is different - very different.

♥♥♥♥:

Honestly, if I hadn't looked at some Youtube videos and discussion boards, I'd probably still be sitting on the first planet getting read to throw my computer out of the window. There is no tutorial and absolutely no hints whatsoever to get you going in the game. I have only gotten as far as I have by basically cheating (i.e. the aforementioned discussion boards) and that is not something you should have to do.

Same thing goes for the cockpit - again, if I had not cheated, I'd probably still be staring at the stupid thing mashing buttons and what not.

I'm still not sure EXACTLY what you are supposed to do, even though I have some ideas that, once again, come from the community for the game. After about five or six planets, I started getting bored with trying to figure out each "puzzle". Supposedly you are supposed to find something called the "anomaly" (I think), but I'll be darned if I know how to find it. Supposedly the stars you see in the sky while on a planet are to be used on your ship for navigation. I'm sorry, I'm not a junior astronomer and have no idea how to do that. Supposedly there is a way to mark constellations (or something) to make it easier, but once again I have no clue how to do that. It's nerve racking.

PROS:

The game is different and I like that. The game has an interesting visual approach and the gameplay is also a bit different when compared to the average first person game. As much as the game has been frustrating me, I still find myeslf drawn back to it and that is a good thing - not many games can do that to me. I'm determined to figure out what makes it tick, even if I have to end up cheating to do so by getting answers via discussion boards, videos, etc.

The only helpful advice I would give would be to pick it up on sale like I did, that may help offset the awkwardness of the game. Do not buy this game if you're looking for a traditional FPS type game, it's nothing like that. There really isn't much to do other than walk around on the planets doing the puzzles (which after you do a couple of them become stupid easy and tedious after a while). I would call this something like a minimalist/surrealist sci-fi type exploration/puzzle game that definitely isn't everyone's cup 'o tea.

Maybe this was meant for MENSA members only, who knows? But I still find myself drawn back to the game which makes me like it for that reason if nothing else. With that said, I still wouldn't recommend this to the average gamer unless you are looking for something a bit off the wall. If you want to fly around space shooting stuff, this definitely isn't the game for you ;)
 
tattoogunman
0

Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2015
This game is a difficult one to for writting a review.

Firstly: I don't even know if I've finished this game. This one will challenge everything you think about playing a game. Sometimes it makes you think that the game is the one playing with you. The mechanics are totaaly new and non-intuitive (which is not bad, it's just different) and apparently you don't have an especific objective at all but wander through the universe and admire how beatiful it is. The soundtrack is settling and the visual are very pretty.
A must-play for everyone looking for a new experience.

Recommandé
45.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 novembre 2015
This game is, uhhh... interesting. It's very indie, there is no doubt about that.

The first level is mostly figuring out how on earth the controls work and what the hell is happening with the star, moon, and buildings and beacons you find on the planet. You will have a lot of moments of thinking "What? What???? What????????????" before going "Oh! I think I get it!" then "Wait what." Once you solve (???) the first planet you get thrown into the cockpit of your spaceship or whatever which is ANOTHER puzzle in itself and, by randomly pressing buttons and hoping you're doing something productive, you'll maybe go to another star.

This has a similar feel to Please Don't Touch Anything, but with even more ???????? and wondering what the hell you just did.

Also, the combination of the controls, the colour scheme, the soundtrack and sound effects, and the weird wobbling makes me feel kind of queasy when I play it. I don't think I can't really handle playing this for more than 15 minutes at a time. Guhhhh.

The $9.99 price is a bit steep in my opinion. I got it when it was on special and I'd recommend waiting for it to be <$5. I'd tentatively recommend it if you can get it for cheaper than the full price.
 
DO YOU REMEMBER LINGERIE

Interesting premise on the starting world - a beautiful example on twisted puzzle without any words of explanation.
Sadly, it all falls apart after that. the promise is that there is a ton of other worlds to explore, but the no-word-of-explanation really takes a toll here. There could be the most amazing experience in your life waiting inside this game, if you have no clue how to progress or what the hell you are sopposed to be doing, you will never get there.

Non recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 octobre 2015
I really liked Noctis IV, but eventually got tired of the low resolution graphics, confusing controls, technical limitations (the unmodified game will only allow you to explore one sector of any planet at the time), the lack of in game story or goals. But it left me with an itch I wanted to scratch. Mirrormoon EP however fails to scratch that itch. While I like the minimalist approach and clean visuals, exploring the planets is boring. Mostly because they aren't proper planets at all. You can see the horizon bend and circumnavigate any planet in five minutes. Even Pluto, now demoted to a dwarf planet, isn't that small and featureless. The planets all look alike except for the colour palette and some minimal debris here and there. Once you've seen one planet, you've really seen them all. There are puzzles on each planet (actually it seems to be the same puzzle over and over again), but I don't want a puzzle game, I want a game about exploration. I want to see beautiful vistas, meet strange animals, find crumbled old ruins, things like that. If you're looking for something similar to Noctis, skip this game. It's an abstract puzzle game that's only posing as a space exploration game.

Comme l'art moderne, certains vont être en extase devant ce jeux, mais la plupart des gens n'y trouveront aucun intérêt. On sent (peut être à tort, mais j'en doute) un genre de prétention aveugle prétendant qu'être indé et développer un jeu conceptuel reviens forcément à faire un bon jeu. A tenter bourré voir plus.

DolgVlaPet
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 aout 2015
Piccolo grande gioco. Ho impiegato un po' a capire.. cosa si dovesse fare. Bhe lo scopo é trovare l' "anomalia" (il come lascio a voi scoprirlo) ma in effetti si tratta piú di un gioco esplorativo: dalla nostra nave spaziale (♥♥♥ una plancia di comando inizialmente molto criptica) , dovremmo spostarci su vari pianeti.

Su di essi troveremo costruzioni, scenari improbabili ma fantastici e strani fenomeni, il tutto caratterizzato da grandi atmosfere e pochi poligoni. I nomi dei pianeti, non sono molto "human-friendly" ma possono essere cambiati da chi li scopre per primo. Il nome sará poi visibile da tutti gli altri players. La galassia che esploreremo, infatti, sará "online" (♥♥♥ nomi che cambiano a seconda delle scoperte) ma in effetti non troveremo mai altri player.

Non pensate di trovare situazioni analoghe a quelle del tutorial iniziale (cioé il primo pianeta che esploreremo): nei luoghi che visiteremo, in effetti, non saranno presenti tutti i puzzle ed enigmi dell' addestramento (sicuramente non saranno presenti nella stessa misura).
In alcuni pianeti sará necessario camminare un po', godersi il panorama , trovare l'oggetto che ci riporterá alla nave e stop. Per questo, é un gioco esplorativo e poco piú.

Un gioco non per tutti che io, peró, ho trovato ESTREMAMENTE affascinante. L'unico problema ? Proprio l'addestramento.
In esso troveremo praticamente TUTTE le possibilitá che oggetti raccoglibili ed enigmi, assieme, possono creare. Non che le combinazioni siano molte ma, per far si che noi possiamo farci un'idea del "da fare" nel gioco, il tutorial durerá comunque qualche minuto. Il problema sta nel fatto che dovremo ripeterlo ogni volta che la galassia verrá rigenerata in seguito alla scoperta dell'anomalia da parte di un giocatore. Veramente non ne capisco il senso. Dopo svariate volte, ho deciso di fermarmi e di non ripeterlo.

A questo proposito segnali anche che sará possibilé selezionare dal menu di gioco, galassie giá "risolte" ma ancora esplorabili. Dato che sono state completate dozzine di galassie vi lascio immaginare il materiale a disposizione. Pensate che ogni galassia poi ha un grandissimo numero di pianeti... avrete veramente molto da esplorare. Nel caso in cui vogliate cercare l'anomalia, vi consiglio di seguire le discussioni su steam su MirrorMoonEP: i giocatori segnaleranno osservatori ed info sull'anomalia da trovare. Fate altrettanto per contribuire.

In conclusione posso dire che é un gioco di nicchia. Le atmosfere colpiscono. Il gameplay é rilassante ma criptico. L'unica cosa: IL TUTORIAL... fatelo fare una volta e basta!
 
Luca Reggiannini

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
51.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 aout 2015
I never write reviews, but the fact that this game has so many negative reviews makes me feel like I have to stand up for it.
For me this game is a complete delight. I played this game for about an hour and became confused and kind of bored after the tutorial planet, but over the next few days I kept thinking about it. Everything about the game is ethereal and inviting in an alien kind of way. I kept coming back knowing that I would see something new and beautiful if I kept looking. It's like chasing a mystery with absolutely no idea what you will find or if you will find anything at all, and to me that is the truest form of exploration. It really makes you feel like you are alone in space searching for who knows what. A lot of the negative reviews state that the worlds are monochromatic and difficult to navigate but I think it adds rather than detracts from the experience.

If you are looking for a game that has clear objectives and goals LOOK ELSEWHERE because this game is NOT for you. If, however, you are looking for a beautiful and immersive experience that at times surprises and delights you with tiny snippets of a larger mystery, then play this now. Keep playing it. Find new things. Feel like you have no idea where you are or what you are doing. Feel discouraged. Then find something new that begins connecting everything else. And keep looking for more. Rinse, repeat. Lovely!
 
Kellorna

Recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2015
Gaming meets art. Well done!

A very cool atmospheric and small indie game, you can play every now and then.
I really like the minimalistic artstyle of the game.
The music is somehow hypnotic and the fact that you fly through space, visiting random planets
on which you do some strange puzzle-action is a pretty interesting concept.

I got to admit, finding the anomaly to "finish" the game is quite a struggle but at the same time a nice mission if you want to claim MirrorMoon EP as "completed".

There is only one thing I would wish for, and that is more interaction with other players in your univers (or season) or at least their planets.
Since this is a kind of multiplayer game and you stumble across several planets occupied by other players some interaction
would be a fun little gimmick ;)

-All in all, still a nice little game.

Évaluation publiée le 21 juillet 2015
Gagné sur Steamgifts contre toute attente il y a quelques temps. J'ai retrouvé un peu ce que j'ai ressenti en jouant à FEZ dans le sens découverte de l'inconnu et apprentissage par l'expérimentation plutôt qu'un tutoriel complet.
Si on adhère, c'est bien prenant. Si vous comptez y jouer un jour, je recommande de commencer sur une saison venant d'être lancée* comme se fût mon cas. Seulement 3% était découvert. J'ai pu explorer et trouver (en premier) ce que je cherchais (et ce que tous les joueurs cherchent en fait) sans que se soit déjà indiqué (puisque les joueurs peuvent nommer les "étoiles").

TL;DR : De l'exploration pure, remplie de mystères que vous apprendrez à comprendre en progressant. Fascinante expérience.

*Une nouvelle saison commence dès que la saison actuelle atteint les 50% d'étoiles explorées. La saison à laquelle j'ai participé était la 74 et était à 8% explorée quand j'ai atteint l'objectif. J'ai été trop sympa d'ailleurs avec le renommage.
Message d'origine sur CPC[forum.canardpc.com].

Recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 juillet 2015
This game is just wonderful. It's not often that you find a game where exploration is required, but you are never guided. This makes the game feel like somewhere that you can get lost in. The puzzles are very difficult, but not having any hints or anything really made them feel rewarding when I finally figured out the solution.

The graphics are very simple, but I think they work quite well. The game is very colorful and lively, despite how baren the planet actually is. The "ship" interface is also very fun to play around with because it has a lot of switches and buttons, most of which don't appear to do anything of significance.

Overall I highly recommend this game, especially if you're looking for something unlike anything you've ever played before.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
16.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 juillet 2015
A serene, wondrous exploration game.
It's all about the atmosphere. about figuring things out, about feeling your place in the universe.
The simplistic graphics and ambient/drone music allow you to feel space like no other game I've played. It's very soothing.
The puzzle on the first planet is brilliant, but unfortunately the randomly generated ones thereafter aren't up to par.
You get to name discovered planets in multiplayer galaxies, and there's an overarching mystery / triangulation puzzle best solved by communicating with other players.
It's a slow game, and it's about feeling, not achieving, so it's not for everyone.
 
House of Eats, Shoots and Leaves
362 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2015
This game is for very specific kinds of people, very specifically me. This is a complex dimensional puzzle game in which the objective is to figure out the objective.
With the exception of keyboard controls (which is pretty much the only in game text you will see), all aspects of the game are learned by doing, entirely at your own pace in a perfectly serene (or maybe ominous) environment.

In Mirrormoon EP, you explore planets with navigational help from a moon that mirrors the planet's surface. The reward for exploring isn't so much what you find, but the very experience of exploring itself and immersing yourself in the game's beautiful abstract world and atmosphere. And perhaps the satisfaction of naming your very own planet for other players to see and explore.

A huge contributor is the game's audio, which (after having played Fotonica) seems pretty characteristic of this developer. Much of the game's beauty and texture exists in the deep and impressive sound rather than visuals. A great refresher from playing games in a time when graphics and visuals are usually seen as a video game's most central attributes, with sound a distant secondary.

I wouldn't recommend Mirrormoon EP to just anyone, but those who I would recommend it to will not have a moment free of my pestering to play this damn great game.
 
Speaking Waters
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
13.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2015
For me, it is hard to decide whether or not to recommend this game. The puzzles range from super easy to hair-tearing-out difficulty. If you are thinking about getting this I recommend buying it during a sale, but even then you may not feel it was worth your money.

Word of advice if you still think you want to get it, despite what the game would have you belive with it's cryptic lines of text when you start a new game and at the end of the tutorial, there is NO PLOT. So don't get your hopes up for one to be revealed to you through the course of the game based on what you see on one of the short youtube let's plays for this game.

Tabris
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 juillet 2015
Over seventy constellations with lots of stars, each containing some kind of a puzzle, be it as simple as "find an orb", or as complicated as "find several, tools, activate pillars, change illumination of the star to activate certain areas, and finally unlock and find orb on the star".
Regular stars can be named, part of them have unique names [undiscovered but named], there are 2 special stars in each constellation, players all start in different parts and uncover and name different stars, everyone travel between them by operating a cockpit, from which you can adjust travelling speed at expense of the fuel usage. Every travel takes a bit of it, and it restores over time of the ship not moving.
Travelling takes real time, so it's best to play windowed and have some book/tv around or other things open in the background.
It's an unique game, its mechanics are very limited, but as a whole concept - it's a completitionist's paradise. You can roam freely, solve puzzles, and be rewarded with a possibility to "mark" your territory, and help everyone uncover the whole constellation in the grander scale.
It's major downside are the controls, they're extremely limited to force player use the unconventional methods of orientation prepared for the game, another thing being the repetition, you will find yourself doing pretty much the same things all the time you play.
I however find it fair, it's a rather bland and simply bad game, but it's amazingly good background game, it's something that you don't focus too much on, but invest bits of your time.
Kind of like playing sudoku in the free time, you play it puzzle by puzzle to reach another milestone, that is what MirrorMoon EP is like, and I think I like it.
 
Shuvack
1,761 produits enregistrés
0

Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2015
One of the most unusual gaming experiences available - where you not only have to explore new worlds, but also your equipment and spaceship. Stunning soundtrack, outstanding graphics design. More than unique controls. Strongly recommended for every open minded grown up gamer!

2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 juin 2015
I love this game and I don't know why. It is simplistic, it is easy to figure out, it has minimal and abstract graphics. Yet, it is quite beautiful, relaxing, and tugs at your curiosity in an amazing way. There is a strange sense of wonderment when you first start, and if you take the game at the pace it was designed for -- slow, enjoying the ride and explore the galaxy -- then that wonderment travels with you and allows for some intriguing gameplay. Even if you only play for an hour, I can't recommend this game highly enough. Give it a try.
 
Trixon

Non recommandé
0.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 juin 2015
Produit remboursé

This game looks amazingly interesting and it sounds really cool... but the gameplay is the most annoying thing I've had to endure in a while.
I was expecting classic FPSs controls, but no. The mouse only rotates the 'MirrorMoon' in the sky, you can't use it to aim or look around, that's what A and D are for... not for going sideways, but for actually turning around... I felt like playing the first Wolfenstein game without a mouse more than 20 years ago...
This could've been an amazing experience, I'm sure; but if the game is not fun to play, it's worthless.
At least I got it super cheap... otherwise I'd be really mad... I'm not playing this again.

Évaluation publiée le 12 juin 2015
Incredible game!! I love the exploration of it! It took me a while to figure out the controls of the space-craft but I honestly had a lot of fun pressing buttons and pulling levers trying to figure it out.
My favourite thing about this game is the crazy objects and structures you can come across as you explore. I found it really immersive and beautiful.
I can understand why someone wouldn't be into this game but if you love atmospheric, minimalist, exploration games this might be your thing.

Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2015
Mostly I'm giving this a reccomendation because I feel it is a bit underrated. The negative reviews are mostly right, and after the first level the game gets a bit yedious and stale. But if you find it 75%-90% off, it's worth it for the first half hour or so of gameplay. It's really interesting and makes you feel as though you are discovering something new. Really really cool as you slowly figure out what you are to do. Unfortunately, once you know the basic steps it becomes far less intriguing.

Évaluation publiée le 4 mai 2015
First, the style is great. Second it succeeds beautifully at tickling my curiosity with the strange ship interface. Unfortunately, all of this falls short, as mirrormoon has some great concepts, mashed together, but don't entirely fit together. Outside the ship, the "puzzles" are best summarized as almost random walking. Yet the environment is a bit dull for a walking simulator.

With not much story line, no real puzzles, a stylish but minimal decor, I've found it hard to get the motivation to complete the game.

On se balade sur une planète sans explication, sans aide, avec un système de cartes inutilement complexe et avec une musique mystérieuse et minimaliste.

Est-ce un jeu ? C'est un concept mais j'ai trouvé ça inutilement complexe.

Oni
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mars 2015
In Mirrormoon EP you're an astronaut (? space traveller? entity?) thrown in a huge galaxy yours to explore. The game is divided into "seasons": every time a season starts a galaxy is randomly generated and the journey for all the players (this is the peculiar online system in Mirrormoon) begins. The main goal is to find the "anomaly", and is achieved by looking for "observatories" and sharing your findings online in the community hub. You can travel with your spaceship by using a strange (and very frustrating) map system.

While visually stunning (if you like that kind of style obviously) and with a 10/10 soundtrack, the game is a little bit boring after some hours in the space. Don't get me wrong, exploring, solving puzzles, and just staring at the wonderful graphics is superb, but the game fails to keep you interested. There are too many stars and too few mechanics, repeated over and over.

BTW if you're looking for a relaxing and visually great game with a super soundtrack buy it, but do not expect the initial enthusiasm to last long.
 
cassetto
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mars 2015
The visual and auditory aesthetic are great. The gameplay is mysterious and challenging at first. SImple yet still challenging puzzle gameplay. It's fun to revisit now and then.

The game seems like it's meant to be enjoyed like an interactive art piece. Kind of a collectible little nugget. The gameplay itself isn't riveting - simple, yet challenging abstract puzzles - but it's fun to have going on while you're doing other stuff on your computer.

9/10

広大な宇宙を旅しながら色んな星に降り立ってパズルを解いたりするゲーム。
最初は何をしたらいいのかもよく分からないが、弄っているうちにだいたいまあなんとかなる。
星に存在する”月”を利用したギミックや奇妙な風景・世界観はなかなかに新しさと独創性を感じるものの、チュートリアルをクリアした後はほとんど同じ内容を延々と繰り返すだけ。新しい星を開拓していくのは妙な快感と中毒性があるのは確かだが、かといって人にオススメできるかというと……ソリティアやフリーセルにのめり込める人なら割とアリかもしれない。

Algot
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
19.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 aout 2014
This is certanly a unique game. you travel through space on a 3d star grid, visit these strange small technicolor planets, solve strange puzzles and name the planets as you go (i've been leaving ciphers in the names :P out of bordom. you can do fun stuff like that if you please). The only drawback is that the puzzle dynamics have to be similar from planet to planet because it's a huge galaxy that's full of an almost endless amount of places to visit. That makes the game very much worth the money because you will get a lot of gameplay out of it. I found the puzzles got addictive and they do throw you a curveball once and a while. It's also great to play when working on something else in the background because you can run it in a window if you want. I always appreciate that. What is cool, is the fact that if you play it in online mode, you and other people and naming stars in the same galaxy. Anyways, I'd definitely recommend it for your collection even if you're looking for a normal adventure game because of the fact that this has almost infinite replay value. It's the most innovative game I've played recently and I usually find games like that gimmicky. I'd usually rather stick to a quintessential game of a genre like puzzle solving adventures but this is one of the few unique genre games I'd recommend
 
tempestmichael

0
Recommandé
21.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 juillet 2014
I was excited by the solid style that this game seems to radiate from every screen shot and marketing image, but what really sold me was the engaging and addicting exploration. I became a space traveler... I learned to navigate the stars through trial and error. Space became meaningful to me. I am now an experienced astronomical navigator. Even making simple pit stops to check out an unnamed star system, that I knew wasn't a destination I was looking for, was really satisfying.

Yes, it's a little slow paced, it requires a little patience, but it rewards you for your curiosity. This game is serious fun, and incredibly beautiful! I can't recommend it enough.

Recommandé
17.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 mai 2014
It's a shame that the side B puzzles aren't as involving as in the tutorial, and naming stars gets old quickly. But this is certainly a relaxing game to play. The music is excellent. The UI luxurious. The controls take some getting used to but once you let go of wanting to look around with the mouse you adjust in time.
The main challenge is really to find the anomaly in the various seasons. While it seems to rely on a certain amount of luck the challenge makes it hard to walk away. This has a "just one more star" feel that keeps you playing until the small hours. I honestly have more fun and productive things to do but I can't stop until I complete that bridge. Still one to get on sale though. 50% seems to be the sweet spot on price.

SidFishious
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2014
I recommend reading this review if you are having a hard time trying to decide on your purchase; and i say this because i went through the same struggle. However, after looking at this game for merely a week, i decided to take it and i can tell you this: MirrorMoon EP is confusing, lonely, and can sometimes feel empty. Though, as these may seem like the games downfall, they soon become lost in MirrorMoon's sense of vast exploration, chilling atmosphere, and the many amazing sights you will see along your travels. At times the game pits you on empty planets and the so called 'puzzle' you are required to accomplish leaves you feeling pointless [Yes, this does feel like a lazy develop meant by the team]. Nevertheless, MM does a great job of making these some what lazy planets as not being forced onto the player, and after spending the 2 or so minutes on the planet, you simply move onto the next; knowing you'll find a greater puzzle and sight. To sum it up, MM takes you to a vast galaxy that holds many wonders to see and explore. The puzzles were not my focus of this game and at times i even forgot this was meant to be a puzzle game so if this part of the game interests you, i would not recommend it. Although, if you are looking for a highly atmospheric exploration game, with a lot to offer, then MirrorMoon EP is your thing.
 
Steven McTowelie
345 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 février 2014
After the initial tutorial planet, a.k.a “Side A”, you are dropped in the depths of space with nary a good luck to guide you. MirrorMoon EP is all about discovery, and you’ll soon find that space is terribly confusing. No explanation is given for your convoluted space craft, leaving you to flip switches randomly until you make your way to an uncharted planet. Each planet has a secret hidden amongst the eerie, alien structures. Once you’ve discovered the secret using an array of environment-altering tools, you get to name the planet, claiming it as your own. Anyone else who comes across your planet will only know it by the name you gave it. While I’m content simply traversing the universe pioneering new worlds, there is a discovery that ends the game. Because the universe is random, you could beat the game within an hour, but you certainly wouldn’t have seen it all. The MirrorMoon universe is magnificently huge. Perhaps too huge. It can be obnoxious to wait fifteen minutes for your ship to make its way to the next destination. The controls could also use some work. I found a joystick to be best for walking on a planet’s surface, but controlling the ship must be done with a mouse and keyboard. Even with its flaws, MirrorMoon EP is an addictive, awe-inspiring experience worthy of any trailblazer’s attention.
 
JAYNLSN
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 janvier 2014
This isn't just a small curiosity, although it looks and sound amazing enough to carry it, there's so much more. This game has a wonderful sense of adventure, or maybe "expedition" would be a better word. You move through countless planets in a search for an anomaly, some planets already explored by other players, some left to be claimed and named by you. It's hard to step away, once you get on a trail. You know it's out there, you don't know how to get there, but you're always exploring and trying to learn more about the galaxy. The game isn't hard, it's not obvious what your goal is and it requires patience, but the actual puzzles are basically navigation challenges, the whole game is one big navigation challenge, consisting of many smaller ones. Although consider that only 1.6% of players have completed the game.

If you're feeling lost, here's a small hint: Find a planet, that has a circled planet in the sky, then find a planet with an observatory, that shows constellations in the sky.
 
Orgel Seira
336 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2014
So remember the 'Cosmos' series, and that trippy 'ship of the imagination' Carl Sagan flew you around in, powered by Vangelis music and Carl's own sense of self-satisfaction? Imagine it was your job to sit on that weird polygonal bridge and figure out how to navigate it through interstellar space. But once you arrive at your destination, instead of learning about natural selection or whatever, you find yourself on a planetoid the Petit Prince would feel comfortable on, armed with an enormous glass laser-pointer, which you use to help you find your way between translucent structures that hold the key to progressing through the game, insomuch as there is a game through which to progress.

MirrorMoon EP isn't about completion, it's about the mystery and wonder of exploration. It's ethereal, ponderous, and oddly engaging. It's Kerbal Space Program without the math or physics or sense of humor. If you're looking for a mellow, atmospheric way to spend a rainy evening, which may haunt you for weeks to come, MirrorMoon EP is a great way to go.
 
HOWDOITURNCAPSLOCKOFF
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2014
It's... beautiful, but I have no idea what is going on. I don't know where I am, how to progress, or how to describe things. I don't even know if I like the game, or am so frustrated with the alien feel as to never want to play it again.
Okay, kidding. I do know I like it. It's just very frustrating.
A side note: for those that get motion sickness with FPS perspective games, that is not an issue for this particular release. I get very nauseated, very quickly with the first person camera on most games, but have not had any hint of that happening here. I think it may be due to the horizon height that was used.
 
feris.sera

5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2013
beautiful. another wonderful proof-of-concept for videogames as art. though the game thrusts the player into a confusing universe without handholding directions every few seconds, i found myself immediately driven to understand it- and understand it entirely of my own volition. too often, i fall into the trap of "i'm lost; time to look up a guide online." here, however, i feel compelled to learn by DOING. every switch in the cockpit has a very visceral look and feel; every tiny pixellated detail on the planet exudes a simple beauty. the game is not about goals so much as it is about the process of exploration. i may never find the solution to "side b" of my game, and that's ok. just living in the universe 'mirror moon' sets out for me makes it all worth the time.
 
nikku_neko
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Props to Santa Ragione for taking a risk with this unique game

Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 décembre 2013
A weird, hauntingly-beautiful game. You walk around on minimalistic planets, collecting various tools that activate bits of each planet's puzzle. It's simplistic and minimalistic, but a pretty cool chill-out game.

My one complaint would be that the multiplayer "name a planet" aspect is kind of lost if arriving at it as late as I did, and it can take a long time to find the exit to each "episode". Also, the puzzles are often rather similar, most involve rotating the moon in some manner, or chasing a trail of markers.

Definitely worthwhile if on sale and you like weird indie games, possibly less-so if not or you don't.
 
aendra
196 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 6 septembre 2013
This game is worth getting. One of the few titles made with unity that I will happily endorse. However if you can't solve simple puzzles, don't get it and go back to Call of Duty. But then again if you can't solve simple puzzles most games are beyond your grasp anyway. Update: Easily a better game than No Man's Sky.
